title: 113_hr4831
content: The Act titled "Twenty-First Century Manufacturing Skills and Jobs Act of 2014" allows for federal matching payments for state new manufacturing jobs training tax credits. The Act authorizes the Secretary of the Treasury to make quarterly payments to eligible community colleges based on new manufacturing job withholding matches for trainees. Eligible community colleges are defined as public institutions offering 2-year associate's degrees accepted for credit towards a bachelor's degree. The Act authorizes the Secretary of the Treasury to make quarterly payments to eligible community colleges based on new manufacturing job withholding matches for trainees. Eligible community colleges offer 2-year associate's degrees accepted for credit towards a bachelor's degree and participate in State new manufacturing jobs training tax credit programs. These programs involve contracts between colleges, manufacturing employers, and trainees for qualified training costs covered by State income tax credits. The Act allows for payments to eligible community colleges based on manufacturing job withholding matches for trainees. Contracts between community colleges, manufacturing employers, and trainees cover qualified training costs through State income tax credits. The employer remits payments to the college instead of the State for training, which is treated as payment for education provided by the college. The Act allows for payments to eligible community colleges for manufacturing job training. Contracts between colleges, employers, and trainees cover training costs through State tax credits. Employers hire trainees for full-time jobs with a minimum wage requirement. The Act allows for payments to eligible community colleges for manufacturing job training. Employers must pay individuals a wage of at least 175 percent of the Federal minimum wage or the amount specified by the State program. Employers also remit State income taxes withheld on behalf of the individual to the community college for training costs. The contract must specify the entire cost of training provided to each individual, which must be reasonable by market standards. Qualified training under this section refers to education or training that equips individuals with the necessary skills for their job, required licenses, certificates aligned with industry standards. To be eligible for a State new manufacturing jobs training tax credit program, the employer must ensure that each trainee is hired for a new job, not a recalled, replacement, or existing job within the past year. The job must align with national or regional industry standards. The employer must hire each trainee for a new job that results in a net increase in employment, and only U.S. employees are considered. All related entities are treated as a single employer for the purposes of this section. For the State new manufacturing jobs training tax credit program, employers and eligible community colleges can collaborate with local workforce investment boards to hire and train individuals. An eligible trainee is someone who received qualified training through a community college under the program and is employed full-time by the employer in the same state. The term "eligible manufacturing employer" refers to a person who employs individuals in manufacturing, with facilities in the US and primary business classified in sectors 31, 32, or 33 of the NAICS. The employer must meet specific criteria for new job creation and training requirements. Out of any sums in the Treasury, such sums as necessary are appropriated ongoing to carry out this section. Withheld State income tax remitted by an eligible manufacturing employer to a community college for training is not considered as employer expenses for tax purposes but as payment of income taxes by the employee. Payments related to eligible trainees are also not considered for tax purposes. Payments made by an employer to a community college for training are not considered income for the trainee. These payments are treated as State income tax deductions for the trainee under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
